attributes.comment:
Re USCIS-2006-0044
USCIS (formerly INS) has no real wish to modernize -- they simply want to
preserve the status quo. My wife, an Irish citizen who first entered this country 43
years ago, was given a "permanent" green card.
In 1996, she was told that she must get a new card -- the excuse at that time
being "we need a card which is computer readable". We spent most of a day at
the then-INS office in Seattle, seeing multiple examples of inefficiency. And we
had to pay what we then considered an exorbitant set of fees ? something like
$90! (Compare that to today's fees of $260 for a renewal!) Won't try to detail the
inefficiencies we saw, because today, ten years later, we saw most of the same
things at USCIS Seattle -- which, while it has a fancy new building, seems to have
the same employees and culture!
Today, we walked into the USCIS office in Seattle, and the first thing my wife had
to do was fill out an "applicant worksheet", which asked for EACH and EVERY
item of the questions she had already answered on her mailed-in application for
renewal of her "green card". How many pieces of paper would eliminating
the ?applicant worksheet? save each year?! How much would this result in cost
savings? God forbid that USCIS employees should be required to match
applications with appointment paperwork! This would require that your records be
computerized -- and I predict that, ten years from now (when my wife will be
expected to pay a fee 300% higher than today's absolutely exorbitant fees), that
still won't have happened! And, TEN YEARS after we paid for a new card to
be ?computer-readable?, we saw a system which is still paper-based!
We saw several examples of out-and-out rudeness by your employees, plus a
defensiveness that shouldn't be there. Whenever someone questioned a
procedure or method, the immediate response was "it's not my fault". Nobody
said it was, folks -- but it IS the fault of the system!
As to director Gonzales' statement that "I need these fees to give the service that
the immigration community expects..." maybe the service is not necessary!
Make the green card permanent, as it was originally!
An extraneous comment -- given two months, I could render the USCIS services
to applicants much more effective -- and do it with half the employees who were
wandering around USCIS Seattle! (Oops ? I know it?s not politically correct to
suggest that civil service positions be questioned, or eliminated!)
Dave Bartholomew
CAPT, USN (Ret)
SailorBart@aol.com
